articles.headline: Confusion and Frustration Reign as Elon Musk Cuts Half of Twitter’s Staff
articles.snippet: The layoffs hit across many divisions, including the engineering and machine learning units, the teams that manage content moderation, and the sales and advertising departments.
articles.abstract: The layoffs hit across many divisions, including the engineering and machine learning units, the teams that manage content moderation, and the sales and advertising departments.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When the ax came down at Twitter on Friday, it did not fall smoothly.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger, Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: How an L.A.P.D. Officer Helped Les Moonves Fight an Assault Complaint
articles.snippet: A captain in the department, who had moonlighted as a security guard for CBS, disclosed to the network information about a confidential complaint made in 2017 against the C.E.O.
articles.abstract: A captain in the department, who had moonlighted as a security guard for CBS, disclosed to the network information about a confidential complaint made in 2017 against the C.E.O.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the New York attorney general’s office announced this week that the former CBS chief executive Leslie Moonves and CBS’s parent company, Paramount Global, had agreed to pay $9.75 million after a state investigation found that they had concealed allegations of sexual misconduct against him, the news was accompanied by another revelation.
articles.byline: By James B. Stewart and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Frustrating and Often Fruitless: The Search for Missing Russian Soldiers
articles.snippet: Russian families searching for loved ones say the system for finding missing soldiers is as disorganized as Vladimir Putin’s military effort, which has been marked by dysfunction from the beginning.
articles.abstract: Russian families searching for loved ones say the system for finding missing soldiers is as disorganized as Vladimir Putin’s military effort, which has been marked by dysfunction from the beginning.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Alina Lobzina

articles.headline: Fed Up With Political Text Messages? Read On.
articles.snippet: In this polarized climate, hundreds of Americans told us they agree on one thing: Campaigns must stop spamming voters’ phones with unwanted political texts.
articles.abstract: In this polarized climate, hundreds of Americans told us they agree on one thing: Campaigns must stop spamming voters’ phones with unwanted political texts.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Boris, Florida is in trouble,” warned one text message seeking campaign donations — and promising 900 percent matching funds — for Senator Marco Rubio of Florida.

articles.headline: YouTube May Have Misinformation Blind Spots, Researchers Say
articles.snippet: The video platform said it had limited the spread of misinformation ahead of Election Day, but new research showed that false narratives continued to slip through.
articles.abstract: The video platform said it had limited the spread of misinformation ahead of Election Day, but new research showed that false narratives continued to slip through.
articles.lead_paragraph: No, China has not worked with Democrats to steal the midterm elections, as some people on YouTube have claimed. Nor has Saudi Arabia.

articles.headline: Family Ties. Political Divisions.
articles.snippet: For Carolyn Broe and her family, the 2022 midterms have unfolded the way they have for countless others: with great bitterness and turbulence.
articles.abstract: For Carolyn Broe and her family, the 2022 midterms have unfolded the way they have for countless others: with great bitterness and turbulence.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the Broe family household, even the mail is divided.

articles.headline: 3 Presidents Swoop Into Pennsylvania, in a Clash That Transcends 2022
articles.snippet: As the midterms come to a close, the establishment politics of the two most recent Democratic presidents met the disruptive force of the last Republican one, with control of Congress at stake.
articles.abstract: As the midterms come to a close, the establishment politics of the two most recent Democratic presidents met the disruptive force of the last Republican one, with control of Congress at stake.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The two parties’ strongest messengers — a fraternity of recent presidents — descended on the pivotal swing state of Pennsylvania on Saturday to open the last weekend of this year’s midterms, rallying their voters in a proxy battle that could define both parties well beyond the election.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Michael C. Bender

articles.headline: How Republicans Fed a Misinformation Loop About the Pelosi Attack
articles.snippet: Within hours of the brutal attack last week on Paul Pelosi, Republican officials and media figures began circulating groundless claims — nearly all of them sinister, and many homophobic — about what had happened.
articles.abstract: Within hours of the brutal attack last week on Paul Pelosi, Republican officials and media figures began circulating groundless claims — nearly all of them sinister, and many homophobic — about what had happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within hours of the brutal attack last week on Paul Pelosi, Republican officials and media figures began circulating groundless claims — nearly all of them sinister, and many homophobic — about what had happened.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Malika Khurana and Stuart A. Thompson

articles.headline: Russia Reactivates Its Trolls and Bots Ahead of Tuesday’s Midterms
articles.snippet: Researchers have identified a series of Russian information operations to influence American elections and, perhaps, erode support for Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Researchers have identified a series of Russian information operations to influence American elections and, perhaps, erode support for Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2022 midterm elections for the latest news and updates.

articles.headline: How Molly Jong-Fast Tweeted Her Way to Liberal Media Stardom
articles.snippet: She wasn’t a political expert. But her Trump-era angst found a following among Democrats — and even the White House is interested.
articles.abstract: She wasn’t a political expert. But her Trump-era angst found a following among Democrats — and even the White House is interested.
articles.lead_paragraph: Molly Jong-Fast had just finished interviewing Vice President Kamala Harris for her podcast when she hopped in an Uber S.U.V. headed to the Century, the Manhattan literary club where she was throwing a book party for the media critic Margaret Sullivan, a friend. The editors of Rolling Stone and Vanity Fair greeted her with hugs. The owner of The New Republic, Win McCormack, stopped to say hello.

articles.headline: What Happens When Crypto Meets Ted Lasso
articles.snippet: A group of American cryptocurrency investors is trying to turn an obscure English soccer club into “the internet’s team,” with a global following of crypto enthusiasts.
articles.abstract: A group of American cryptocurrency investors is trying to turn an obscure English soccer club into “the internet’s team,” with a global following of crypto enthusiasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Preston Johnson, a soft-spoken cryptocurrency millionaire with a long, bushy, brown beard, leaned forward in his seat, fists clenched, surveying his empire. He wasn’t perched on a mega yacht or enjoying any of the other ostentatious perks of crypto wealth. The setting was humbler: a small soccer stadium in a town about 30 miles south of London, where the lowest-ranked team in England’s professional leagues was battling for survival.

articles.headline: Confidence, Anxiety and a Scramble for Votes Two Days Before the Midterms
articles.snippet: As candidates made their closing arguments on Sunday, Democrats braced for potential losses even in traditionally blue corners of the country while Republicans predicted a red wave.
articles.abstract: As candidates made their closing arguments on Sunday, Democrats braced for potential losses even in traditionally blue corners of the country while Republicans predicted a red wave.
articles.lead_paragraph: The turbulent midterm campaign rolled through its final weekend on Sunday as voters — buffeted by record inflation, worries about their personal safety and fears about the fundamental stability of American democracy — showed clear signs of preparing to reject Democratic control of Washington and embrace divided government.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Jennifer Medina and Jonathan Weisman

articles.headline: As Midterms Near, Biden Faces a Nation as Polarized as Ever
articles.snippet: President Biden had hoped to preside over a moment of reconciliation after the turmoil of the Trump years. But the fever of polarizing politics has not broken ahead of Tuesday’s midterm elections.
articles.abstract: President Biden had hoped to preside over a moment of reconciliation after the turmoil of the Trump years. But the fever of polarizing politics has not broken ahead of Tuesday’s midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. — Before heading into a community center for a campaign rally the other day, President Biden stopped to speak to the overflow crowd that could not squeeze into the small facility.

articles.headline: Reality of Irving’s Import to Nike: ‘They Can Drop Him’
articles.snippet: Kyrie Irving’s relationship with the athletic apparel giant has been lucrative, but his recent post about an antisemitic movie has led the company to suspend its dealings with him.
articles.abstract: Kyrie Irving’s relationship with the athletic apparel giant has been lucrative, but his recent post about an antisemitic movie has led the company to suspend its dealings with him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nike is facing plenty of challenges this year.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Jordyn Holman

articles.headline: Trump-DeSantis Rift Grows, With Dueling Rallies in Florida
articles.snippet: The Republican Party’s top two stars are campaigning, separately, in the midterms’ last days.
articles.abstract: The Republican Party’s top two stars are campaigning, separately, in the midterms’ last days.
articles.lead_paragraph: SUN CITY CENTER, Fla. — Former President Donald J. Trump hasn’t endorsed Gov. Ron DeSantis this year because, as he has explained, his fellow Floridian never asked. Mr. DeSantis didn’t attend the Trump rally on Sunday in Miami, his allies said, because he wasn’t personally invited.
articles.byline: By Michael C. Bender and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Even as Challenges Mount, Europeans Stick by Ukraine
articles.snippet: Inflation and anxiety over nuclear weapons may be eating into some popular support for the war, but key governments remain insulated from the pressures for now.
articles.abstract: Inflation and anxiety over nuclear weapons may be eating into some popular support for the war, but key governments remain insulated from the pressures for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — The high cost of living is provoking strikes, protests and widespread grumbling. Talk about nuclear weapons has heightened anxieties and encouraged some to demand rapid negotiations. And President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is wooing politicians, including many from populist parties on the right and the left who have flirted with him in the past.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Catherine Porter

articles.headline: An Engine of Upward Mobility Struggles to Capture Opportunities in Tech
articles.snippet: Students at the City University of New York are increasingly graduating with degrees in technology. A new report details the obstacles they face in landing jobs.
articles.abstract: Students at the City University of New York are increasingly graduating with degrees in technology. A new report details the obstacles they face in landing jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The technology industry has been a leading engine of growth for good-paying jobs in New York City over the past decade. That trend continued through the pandemic, but a new report casts doubt on how widely the tech-fueled prosperity is being shared.

articles.headline: China’s Business Elite See the Country That Let Them Thrive Slipping Away
articles.snippet: The business class, which shunned politics, is now questioning if there is still a place for it in a system dominated by one ruler, Xi Jinping.
articles.abstract: The business class, which shunned politics, is now questioning if there is still a place for it in a system dominated by one ruler, Xi Jinping.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, China’s business class had an unspoken contract with the Communist Party: Let us make money and we’ll turn a blind eye to how you use your power.

articles.headline: Fears and Suspicion Hang Over Voting on Cusp of Election Day
articles.snippet: Even as voting goes smoothly, the 2022 midterm elections have exposed the toll Donald J. Trump’s falsehoods have taken on American democracy.
articles.abstract: Even as voting goes smoothly, the 2022 midterm elections have exposed the toll Donald J. Trump’s falsehoods have taken on American democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Voters go to the polls on Tuesday after a campaign season so filled with conspiracy theories and lies that officials worry they will undermine confidence in the election no matter how the balloting goes.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Charles Homans
